entry.et: Middle English seen, from Old English sēon; akin to Old High German sehan to see and perhaps to Latin sequi to follow sue

def.dt: :to perceive by the eye
:to perceive or detect as if by sight
:to have experience of :undergo see army service
:to come to know :discover
:to be the setting or time of the last fifty years have seen a sweeping revolution in science Barry Commoner
:to form a mental picture of :visualize can still see her as she was years ago
:to perceive the meaning or importance of :understand
:to be aware of :recognize sees only our faults
:to imagine as a possibility :suppose couldn't see him as a crook
:examine watch want to see how she handles the problem
:read
:to read of
:to attend as a spectator see a play
:to take care of :provide for had enough money to see us through
:to make sure see that order is kept
:to regard as :judge
:to prefer to have I'll see him hanged first I'll see you dead before I accept your terms
:to find acceptable or attractive can't understand what he sees in her
:to call on :visit
:to keep company with especially in courtship or dating had been seeing each other for a year
:to grant an interview to :receive the president will see you now
:accompany escort see the guests to the door
:to meet (a bet) in poker or to equal the bet of (a player) :call
:to give or pay attention
:to look about
:to have the power of sight
:to apprehend objects by sight
:to perceive objects as if by sight
:to grasp something mentally
:to acknowledge or consider something being pointed out see, I told you it would rain
:to make investigation or inquiry
:to attend to :care for
:to have a common viewpoint :agree
:to become very angry
:to discover or realize a usually obscured truth
:to become publicly known or available (as through publication) manuscripts that will never see the light of day
:hallucinate
:to grasp the true nature of saw through the scheme
:to attend to :care for

entry.et: Middle English se, from Anglo-French sé, see, from Latin sedes seat; akin to Latin sedēre to sit sit

def.dt: :cathedra
:a cathedral town
:a seat of a bishop's office, power, or authority
:the authority or jurisdiction of a bishop
Thomas Jefferson Jackson 1866–1962 Am. astron. & math.
:transparent 1
:the see of the pope
:a general survey :evaluation inspection
:something (as a film) that must or should be seen

entry.et: from the words (as supposedly spoken by American Indians) no see um you don't see them

def.dt: :biting midge
